   INTERNATIONAL

   CONCORDE-CRASH _ GONESSE, France _ We try to sum up the
ill-fated crash of Air France Flight 4590, the first-ever disaster
on a Concorde supersonic transport jet. Developing. (Roughton, Cox
News Service).

   Expected to move Fri., July 28, on the NYT Wire.

   COLOMBIA-INTRO _ With the highest murder and kidnapping rates in
the world, a raging civil war, the worst recession in memory and
plummeting public confidence in the army and the government,
Colombia is facing the most dire crisis in its history. Thousands
of people are fleeing the country, while human rights activists
estimate another 1 to 2 million have been displaced internally by
repeated attacks by leftist guerrillas and right-wing paramilitary
groups. We profile two groups _ kidnap victims and displaced people
_ as a window into everyday life in Colombia. (Williams, Cox News
Service)

   WITH

   COLOMBIA-KIDNAP _ BOGOTA, Colombia _ The families come to the
national radio station each week, clutching hand-written notes they
hope will somehow reach their kidnapped relatives. With an average
of 8 kidnappings a day, Colombia is a nation living in fear.
Leftist guerrillas and paramilitary groups have turned kidnapping
into a big business _ some 3,000 victims were snatched last year -
to raise money for their armies. We profile a few families of
kidnap victims who hope against hope they will somehow see their
loved ones again. (Williams, Cox News Service).

   WITH

   COLOMBIA-DISPLACED _ BOGOTA, Colombia _ Libia Barahona watched
warring leftist guerrillas and right-wing paramilitaries battle in
her remote village for months, dodging bullets and hiding with her
five children. Finally, she fled, abandoning her small store and
restaurant, eventually making her way to Bogota, where she is now
homeless. Barahona is one more victim in the tidal wave of 1 to 2
million Colombians - mostly rural peasants - displaced by the
country's civil war. Human rights activists fear the US aid package
may only increase the flow of refugees as poor campesinos are
forced out of the countryside by crop eradication programs and the
escalating war between guerrillas and the Colombian army.
(Williams, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS. Expected to move on the
NYT Wire.

   MEXICO-MIGRATION _ SAN FELIPE TORRES MOCHAS, Mexico _ Like
millions of other young Mexicans, Eusebio de Haro set out for the
United States in May, confident he'd find work like he did before.
Instead De Haro was shot to death, allegedly, by an elderly Texas
rancher after he and another young man knocked on his door to ask
for water in a remote area near the Rio Grande. The option to the
United States for work is as deeply ingrained in De Haro's home
state as the Virgin of Guadalupe. But it is an option that appears
to be getting more deadly every day for those who choose to cross
the border illegally. Migration is probably the toughest of all
issues between these two countries. And Mexican President-elect
Vicente Fox, who is from De Haro's home state, has heightened the
profile even more, suggesting more visas for Mexican workers and
working toward an open border for the free flow of labor in as
little as 10 years. (Ferriss, Cox News Service).

   WITH MIGRATION-SIDE _ GUANAJUATO, Mexico _ Migration has
affected some towns in Fox's Guanajuato state where state social
workers attend to abandoned families and other problems. They're
also encouraging successful migrants to invest in communities to
create jobs there. These are towns that send construction workers
to Arkansas, laborers and harvestors to Texas and Georgia and
others states. We tell it from the perspective of a young social
worker we watched in action. (Ferriss, Cox News Service). WITH
PHOTOS.

   With information for locator map; chart on migration.

   Expected to move on the NYT Wire.

   NATION

   GOP-CITY _ PHILADELPHIA _ A look at the pleasures and hassles
that await those attending the Republican National Convention this
week. (Dart, Cox News Service)

   GOP-INTERNET _ PHILADELPHIA _ Dot-com political sites gear up
for their first big test of convention coverage. (Glass, Cox News
Service)

   WITH

   INTERNET-GRID _ What's being offered on the Web by dot-com
companies covering the Republican National Convention. (Cox News
Service)

   MILLER-MONEY _ When Zell Miller left the governor's office, his
political capital was large but his financial portfolio was another
matter. His net worth was only about $300,000 _ a paltry sum for a
man of his age and stature. He soon set out to change that,
however, joining the boards of seven corporations and investing in
some of those firms. Now that he has been appointed to the U.S.
Senate, he's disengaging from those new business interests_ and, by
all accounts, making a substantial financial sacrifice. (Judd,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   (Editors: This is the CoxNet FOCUS page for the week. The layout
will be available Friday afternoon)

   COXNET FOCUS 0728: GOP CONVENTION _ Political conventions are
long on PR these days, but an educated viewer can read between the
lines. Here is a viewer's guide to the GOP convention next week in
Philadelphia. (Baxter, Cox News Service)

   WITH

   GOP INTERNET _ Dot-com political sites gear up for their first
big test of convention coverage. (Glass, Cox Washington Bureau)

   ATTENTION EDITORIAL, OP-ED AND POLITICAL EDITORS

   ``The people who are in charge of explaining American politics
to the American people don't understand American politics. They
think it's largely about imagery, but it's really about reality.
The national conventions are the occasions when the swing voters
finally pause to take note of the real national circumstances that
will determine their votes.'' This excerpt is from Dayton Daily
News editorial writer Martin Gottlieb's new e-book _ ``Campaigns
Don't Count: How the Media Get American Politics All Wrong.'' The
book, which is available free in its entirety at
www.coxnews.com/2000, is the topic of a full page layout that will
run on Sunday, July 30 in the Daily News. The page will be
available Wednesday, July 26 after 5 p.m. EDT with an embargo until
the 30th. It can be found via the Budget Tool by doing a WAN search
with a rundate of 0730, a location of Dayton and a category of
Op-Ed and Editorial. If you have questions or need more
information, contact Daily News Editorial Page Editor Ellen Belcher
at 937 225-2286 (ebelcher(at)coxojio.com) or the CoxNet desk in
Atlanta at 404 526-5456.

   BUSINESS

   BERNIE-MARCUS _ Bernie Marcus, a former stand-up comic and
hypnotist, has been the best icon Home Depot could hope for in the
company's 20-year history. Tough-talking and charming at once,
Marcus is Home Depot's do-it-yourself culture personified.
Colleagues describe him as a Pied Piper; employees routinely line
up for his autograph. But as the company prepares to double in size
over the next few yeasrs to nearly 2,000 stores, how is HD getting
the ``bleed orange'' message out to the masses? (Bond, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   BERNIE-SIDE _ A computerized kiosk has become Home Depot's star
recruiter as the retailer tries to find an army of workers to fill
its growing chain of warehouse stores. The home improvement giant
needs to tackle what seems like a nerve-racking project in this
tight U.S. labor market. Atlanta-based Home Depot plans to open
about 900 stores over the next three years, and it will have to
hire more than 200,000 workers to do that. Currently, new stores
open on the average of one every 43 hours. No problem, says Home
Depot. Thanks to a new automated procedure, the retailer has turned
the hiring process into a near-science. (Bond, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   PARENTS _ A survey by the Lutheran Brotherhood suggests that
rather than being less productive and distracted or overburdened,
parents consider themselves more productive after the kids come
along. We'll take a look at what the numbers say and talk to some
parents about their productivity. (Mallory, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SCIENCE/HEALTH

   HUNLEY _ For most of the 136 years since it became an icon of
naval history, the Confederate submarine H.L. Hunley has been
buried in the soft mud at the bottom of Charleston Harbor - lost,
then found, but always surprisingly safe from the ravages of time.
All that will change next month when a giant crane lifts the
Hunley, encrusted with marine growth, from its watery grave into
the sunlight of a Carolina summer. For Civil War and submarine
buffs the world over, raising the Hunley will mark the realization
of a dream. For archaeologists, it is the start of a race against
time _ one that will ultimately determine how many secrets locked
inside in the 40-foot submarine are uncovered. ``The minute the
Hunley reaches the surfaces, we will have a ticking time bomb on
our hands,'' says'' says Maria Jacobsen, the archaeologist who will
direct the excavation of the submarine in a state-of-the-art
laboratory at the old Charleston Navy Yard. (Toner, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   BONES _ A look at what scientists expect to find inside the
Confederate submarine when the Hunley is raised from four miles off
Sullivans Island. Confederate heritage groups already have prepared
wooden coffins for the remains of nine sailors they believe drowned
when the Hunley sank in 1864. Scientists say depending upon how
well the remains were preserved, they could more than bones and
teeth - possibly clothing, buttons, even brain matter. (Burritt,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   LIFESTYLE

   BLACKWOMEN-POLL _ AJC Southern Poll shows that the group most
unhappy with male-female relations is black women. Experts and poll
respondents opine on why. (Miller, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   TRAVEL-CANADA-HORSE _ Quebec Province, Canada _ Taking a
five-day horseback ride through the rural Gaspe Peninsula in Quebec
Province. Every night, the ride ends at an inn, bed and breakfast
or small hotel. The accommodations and food range from basic to
luxurious, with the added benefit of getting to know French
Canadians in their own homes. But the main attraction is the
horses. Riders spend five to seven hours a day in the saddle
astride well-trained, well-cared-for mounts. They respond to
commands and expect to be reined. Let your attention wander and
your horse will, too. (Eckstein, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
PHOTOS.

   WITH

   HORSE-RIDE-QUEBEC PROVINCE, Canada _ Even the horses spoke
French, or at least understood French commands, on our five-day
horseback ride around the Gaspe Peninsula last fall. Here's a trail
journal. . . (Eckstein, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS.

   FASHION

   FASHION-TOERINGS _ More and more people are adorning their feet
with elaborate toenail polish designs and foot jewelry. Amy Winn
gives us a glimpse at Atlantans including a man who wears toenail
polish and at the array of merchandise in stores to give you happy
feet. (Winn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   BOOKS

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET BOOKS 0729: WALKING _ Writing about walking, it turns
out, is almost as plentiful as writing about writing, yet much of
it, as Rebecca Solnit points out in ``Wanderlust: A History of
Walking,'' is ``episodic,'' with ``no overarching plot.''
(Rothstein, N.Y. Times News Service) Art includes a 4-column color
photo of a man walking in the woods and a 6-pica color photo of the
book jacket.

   WITH: PURPLE CANE ROAD _ After appearing in 11 novels, James Lee
Burke's Louisiana police Detective Dave Robicheaux should be as
stale as a month-old box of Krispy Kremes. But thanks to Burke's
ability to create new challenges from a fascinating gallery of
rogues, he's back with renewed vigor in ``Purple Cane Road.''
(O'Briant, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 6-pica
color photo of a book jacket.

   WITH: AMERICAN RHAPSODY _ Joe Eszterhas' ``American Rhapsody''
is an entertaining but thoroughly salacious read that's part
journalistic tale, part racy fiction and likely to rile a lot of
important people and their fans. (Morris, Austin
American-Statesman) Art includes a 6-pica color photo of a book
jacket.

   WITH: PUBLISHING NOTES _ If you've finished reading the first
chapter of Stephen King's online novel, ``The Plant,'' and are
looking for something else scary, click onto www.contentville.com
for a first-chapter preview of Anne Rice's next book. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WITH: SKUBE ON BOOKS _ In his best work, McMurtry's bittersweet
humor has played counterpoint to the elegiac. That note is
conspicuously absent in ``Roads.'' Art includes a 6-pica color
photo of a book jacket.

   WITH: N.Y. TIMES BEST SELLERS LIST

   COXNET ENTERTAINMENT _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Lifestyles page
for the current week. The subject this week is entertainment. This
layout is now available.)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES 0729: DIVERSITY `WAKE-UP CALL': More
African-Americans will be appearing in more noticeable roles in TV
series premiering in the fall, a result of pressure put on the
networks by the NAACP a year ago. (Kloer, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo of actor
Mykelti Williamson, who will be starring in ``The Fugative,'' a
1-column color photo of Jessica Alba, whio will be appearing in
``Dark Angel,'' and a 2-column color photo of David Allen Grier and
Delta Burke, who will be starring in ``DAG.''

   WITH: COMMENTARY _ Sandy Grushow, chairman of Fox Entertainment
Group, is apprehensive about the new television season. He believes
Fox has too many new series and too many that are dark. (Holloway,
Austin American-Statesman).

   WITH: MOVIE ROUNDUP _ `Scary Movie,'' and ``Road Trip'' appear
to be big winners in Hollywood, where the films are reaping big
gains in comparison to their initial investments. (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 2-column color photo of Martin
Lawrence, who stars in ``Big Momma.''

   WITH: MOVIE BOX _ A box showing the winners and losers of the
summer movie season.

   BOOKS-ROLLINS _ When is a best seller not a best seller? Well,
if it's a children's book, it might be a different kind of best
seller than you thought. Next question: When is a children's book
not quite a children's book? Well, maybe when lots of adults are
reading it, too. We're beating around the bush here to get to the
same place everybody seems to be getting these days _ which of
course is to Harry Potter Land, a magical place that's changing
more than just the reading habits of millions of children.
(Rollins, Dayton Daily News)

   REVta Journal-Constitution)

   WEB-RADIO _ Talk radio isn't just for broadcast anymore. You can
get it on the Web, too. We track down some of the usual talk radio
suspects online, and hook up to some that you might not know.
(DeVault, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   GANGSTA-TOUR _ The man who set gangster rap to music 13 years
ago is bringing his first-ever national tour to Atlanta on Friday.
The fact that producer Dr. Dre's on a 40-city tour with the artists
that have made the most of his sinister rhythms (Eminem, Snoop
Dogg) is kind of like an official announcement that hip-hop's most
offensive sub-genre is back. Big time. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   SPORTS

   AUTO RACING

   (The CoxNet weekly NASCAR page is still available for Sunday
use, except on weeks when the race is on Saturday.)

   OLYMPICS

   OLY-SOCCER _ Climbing up the professional soccer ladder _ and
very quickly _ has been the story of Josh Wolff's young career in
Major League Soccer. A knee injury on the eve of the playoffs last
year has been about the only thing to slow down the Parkview High
graduate, who's earned a place on the U.S. Olympic team. The
23-year-old striker for the Chicago Fire also is getting an ample
chance to start this season for the first time and has continued a
knack for scoring clutch goals. Wolff also was recently featured in
an Olympic pictorial in Rolling Stone magazine. On Sunday in
Indianapolis, the U.S. team plays one of only two matches between
now and Sydney against the Bolton Wanderers of the English First
Division. (Parker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TRAVEL-CANADA-HORSE _ Quebec Province, Canada _ Taking a
five-day horseback ride through the rural Gaspe Peninsula in Quebec
Province. Every night, the ride ends at an inn, bed and breakfast
or small hotel. The accommodations and food range from basic to
luxurious, with the added benefit of getting to know French
Canadians in their own homes. But the main attraction is the
horses. Riders spend five to seven hours a day in the saddle
astride well-trained, well-cared-for mounts. They respond to
commands and expect to be reined. Let your attention wander and
your horse will, too. (Eckstein, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
PHOTOS.

   OLYMPICS

   OLY-SOCCER _ Climbing up the professional soccer ladder _ and
very quickly _ has been the story of Josh Wolff's young career in
Major League Soccer. A knee injury on the eve of the playoffs last
year has been about the only thing to slow down the Parkview High
graduate, who's earned a place on the U.S. Olympic team. The
23-year-old striker for the Chicago Fire also is getting an ample
chance to start this season for the first time and has continued a
knack for scoring clutch goals. Wolff also was recently featured in
an Olympic pictorial in Rolling Stone magazine. On Sunday in
Indianapolis, the U.S. team plays one of only two matches between
now and Sydney against the Bolton Wanderers of the English First
Division. (Parker, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
